@kennknowles Please take a look if you have time.

The reasoning to swap everything to be a custom coder is to remove the need to create URNs and specifications for all the non-Fn API coders. Swapping to using customcoder is one way of freeing us up in the future to define a specification equivalent to what it encodes and provide an URN.

OK, that sounds fine as a temporary measure. Obviously many of these coders already exist as a well-defined language-independent format. But it is fine to not commit to it right now.
(We can also always just bump the URN version)

There is no restriction that a class that extends `CustomCoder` be a class that serializes purely via Java serialization. The mechanism to actually register custom urn-based serializers isn't implemented yet. Coders which extend `CustomCoder` and have no specifically defined Serialization mechanism (e.g. shared urn and payload format) will be serialized via Java, but the idea is that we'll be able to register additional coder serializations (e.g. `NullableCoder`, `MapCoder`, etc)

My understanding of the "meaning" of `StandardCoder` is that it's a coder that *must* be understood by the runner.
(Incoming conflicts with FileSystems conversion -- please hold review until those are resolved, as they solve some key API issues for cross-OS uses of the windowing support)

executed outside the scope of a pipeline.

LGTM

An actual important change that occurred here is this:

 - Previously, the `WindowingStrategy` combined the `OutputTimeFn` with the `WindowFn` to make a new custom `OutputTimeFn` that shifted timestamps as needed.
 - Now that it is an enum, this cannot be done. So now the runner has to be sure to pass all input timestamps through `WindowFn.getOutputTime(...)` before using the timestamp combiner.

retest this please

In the past we've avoided using CustomCoder for most core coders due to it's use of Java Serializable. The Dataflow runner supports updating a running pipeline, and will fail the update if the coder appears to change. Using Serializable to define the coder makes it very susceptible to change on otherwise innocuous updates.
Can this be rebased now that pr2184 is merged?
R: @lukecwik

The plan is to drop the usage of Jackson as the payload format which was
convenient when adding to CloudObject and instead allow coders to provide
converters from Java/Python Coder -> Beam Runner API Coder (proto). This
would allow for Coders to define and maintain a stable format. Is there a
concern if this work to finish the Coder -> Beam Runner API Coder (proto)
occurs after first stable release?

Coders can provide an encoding id (Coder.getEncodingId) which can be used
along with the class name to identify a Coder. As far as I can tell, none
of our coders currently use this.
